Introduction

Cardiac tamponade is a life-threatening condition resulting from the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial sac (eg, pericardial effusion), leading to restricted diastolic filling of the heart, reduced stroke volume, and obstructive shock.  It is a medical emergency that requires prompt recognition and intervention.

Risk factors



Any condition that causes pericardial effusion can lead to tamponade; this includes all etiologies of pericarditis such as infection (eg, viruses, tuberculosis), uremia, autoimmune disease (eg, systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis), and malignancy.  Hypothyroidism is a rare cause of pericardial effusion and tamponade.  In addition, cardiac trauma (eg, injury, free wall rupture) or invasive procedures (eg, cardiac ablation, cardiothoracic surgery) can result in blood accumulation in the pericardial space and lead to tamponade.  Aortic dissection with extension into the aortic root and rupture into the pericardial space is an occasional cause of tamponade.

Pathophysiology



There is normally a small volume of fluid within the pericardial space (eg, <50 mL).  Cardiac tamponade occurs when excess fluid accumulates within the pericardial space and, due to restricted expansion of the pericardial sac, begins to increase pericardial pressure.  As pericardial pressure rises it begins to exceed the normal diastolic filling pressures of the heart and causes compression of the cardiac chambers; the relatively low-pressure right-sided chambers are affected first, with restricted diastolic filling of the right atrium and right ventricle.  As these chambers become unable to fill, less blood is pumped to the left side of the heart and cardiac output decreases, resulting in hypotension.  Because the obstruction to blood flow is primarily right-sided, pulmonary edema is not expected.  As tamponade progresses, diastolic pressures in all 4 cardiac chambers increase and equalize with pericardial pressure (and with one another), eliminating the normal pressure gradients within the heart and stagnating blood flow (and causing obstructive shock (

image 1
)).



Cardiac tamponade is classified as acute or subacute based on the rate and volume of pericardial fluid accumulation.



  • Acute tamponade occurs due to rapid fluid accumulation (eg, bleeding into the pericardial space).  Because the normally noncompliant pericardium does not have time to adapt, a small amount of pericardial fluid (eg, 100-200 mL) can dramatically increase pericardial pressure and impair cardiac function.
  • Subacute tamponade typically develops from chronic processes that cause the slow accumulation of pericardial fluid (eg, malignancy, renal failure), giving the pericardium time to progressively stretch and increase compliance.  The stretched pericardium may accommodate up to 2 liters of fluid before pericardial pressure begins to rise and compromise cardiac function.

Clinical presentation

Beck triad



The classic Beck triad of cardiac tamponade presents as follows (

figure 1
):



  • Jugular venous distension occurs due to elevated right atrial pressure.  It is highly sensitive (ie, usually present) but sometimes may be difficult to detect on physical examination.
  • Hypotension develops due to impaired diastolic filling and reduced cardiac output.  It is only moderately sensitive as it is a late finding in subacute tamponade.
  • Muffled heart sounds can occur due to dampening of sound by the accumulated pericardial fluid.  It is poorly sensitive, likely in part because it can be subjective and difficult to detect on physical examination.


However, the complete triad is seen only in a minority of patients.

Acute vs subacute tamponade



The clinical features can vary with acute vs subacute tamponade (

).



  • With acute tamponade, cardiac dysfunction rapidly develops (eg, within minutes) with resulting hypotension and shock (and reflex tachycardia).  Acute-onset chest pain may be present.
  • With subacute tamponade, the presentation is more gradual (eg, several days to weeks) and often more subtle.  Patients can have exertional dyspnea and fatigue (due to impaired cardiac output), chest discomfort or fullness, and lower extremity edema.  Exertional lightheadedness or syncope may also occur.  Tachycardia is typically present before clinically apparent hypotension develops (because the reflexive increase in heart rate can maintain relatively compensated cardiac output at rest).  As fluid continues to accumulate, hypotension and shock can abruptly develop once a critical pericardial volume/pressure is reached.


In neither acute nor subacute tamponade are pulmonary edema (eg, lung crackles) or hypoxemia typically expected.  In both cases, a narrow pulse pressure is typically present once hypotension develops, reflecting reduced stroke volume.  An attenuated y descent is typically seen in the jugular venous pulse waveform due to compression of the right ventricle and impaired diastolic filling (

figure 2
).

Pulsus paradoxus



Pulsus paradoxus is a helpful finding seen in most patients once tamponade develops.  It is an exaggerated drop in systolic blood pressure (>10 mm Hg) during inspiration that results from the right and left ventricle having to compete for limited space (ie, ventricular interdependence) (

figure 3
).



  • Normally, there is a slight drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration because the reduced intrathoracic pressure with inspiration pulls blood into the lungs and right ventricle while at the same time slightly reducing left ventricular filling and stroke volume.
  • In tamponade, the right ventricle cannot expand outward to accommodate increased blood return during inspiration, so the increased blood return forces the interventricular septum to bow into the left ventricle.  This further reduces left ventricular filling and stroke volume, creating an exaggerated drop in systolic blood pressure.


Pulsus paradoxus is highly sensitive but only moderately specific for tamponade as it is also seen in other conditions (eg, severe asthma).

ECG findings



  • Tachycardia (highly sensitive but nonspecific)
  • Low-voltage QRS complexes due to either dampening of electrical signals or impaired cardiac function (neither sensitive nor specific)
  • Electrical alternans (
    figure 4
    ):  beat-to-beat variation in QRS complex amplitude due to oscillation of the heart within the fluid-filled pericardial sac (poorly sensitive but fairly specific for tamponade or large pericardial effusion)

Chest x-ray findings



  • In acute tamponade, chest x-ray is usually unremarkable (the cardiac silhouette is not enlarged due to relatively low volume of pericardial fluid).
  • In subacute tamponade, the large volume of pericardial fluid creates the classic enlarged and globular-shaped cardiac silhouette (
    image 2
    ).

Diagnosis



The diagnosis should be suspected based on a consistent clinical presentation.  Echocardiography is used to confirm the diagnosis as it allows for visualization of pericardial fluid and evaluation for characteristic hemodynamic findings (

image 3
):



  • Right atrial end-diastolic collapse is the earliest and most sensitive sign of cardiac tamponade.  It is also highly specific.
  • Right ventricular diastolic collapse is less sensitive but is also highly specific.


Although not typically performed, right heart catheterization is the diagnostic gold standard and can be helpful in confirming unclear cases.  It characteristically shows elevation and equalization of cardiac diastolic pressures (ie, right atrial pressure = right ventricular diastolic pressure = pulmonary capillary wedge pressure [left atrial pressure]), with the hemodynamic abnormalities resolving upon drainage of pericardial fluid.

Management



Intravenous fluids can temporarily improve blood pressure by increasing right atrial pressure.  Definitive management requires urgent/emergent removal of pericardial fluid to reduce pericardial pressure and restore the normal diastolic pressure gradients within the heart.



Treatment modalities include:



  • Pericardiocentesis:  This involves insertion of a needle below the xiphoid process or between the ribs at the cardiac apex to drain pericardial fluid and alleviate cardiac compression.
  • Surgical intervention:  In cases of recurrent or refractory tamponade, surgical procedures such as a pericardial window or pericardiectomy may be necessary.

Complications



Complications of cardiac tamponade include multiorgan failure (resulting from shock) and sudden cardiac arrest (usually pulseless electrical activity) leading to death.  Recurrent tamponade is a concern in patients with a persistent underlying etiology (eg, malignancy).  Complications of treatment include cardiac trauma and bleeding.

Prognosis



Untreated cardiac tamponade is uniformly fatal.  With prompt and successful pericardial drainage, tamponade is reversible and the short-term prognosis is favorable.  The long-term prognosis is mostly related to the underlying etiology (ie, favorable in many cases but poor for life-limiting etiologies such as malignancy).

Summary



Cardiac tamponade is a life-threatening emergency characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial sac, impeding proper heart function and leading to decreased cardiac output and shock (

).  Risk factors include conditions causing pericardial effusion such as infections, autoimmune diseases, and trauma.  Diagnosis is primarily based on clinical presentation and echocardiography.  The classic Beck triad (jugular venous distension, hypotension, muffled heart sounds) is seen in a minority of patients.  Management involves fluid resuscitation and urgent pericardial fluid drainage through pericardiocentesis or surgical interventions.
